instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery
threads.message:
[PLAIN][SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery[/PLAIN]

Hi there,

Customer came in with a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> motherboard that did not power on, replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> because bad voltages out and it booted again without issues.
The device has no signs of water damage or bad prior repairs.

The system does not detect a battery, It will not boot off one but if you pull the charger the device will not power off and keep on running from the battery (Until the OS finishes going in suspend). Once in suspend the system dies again while only connected to the battery


Pretty sure this is an issue with the <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA</SIGNAL> / SCL lines, but they seem to be doing ok-ish. I've seen 3.3V on SDA and pretty sure I've seen 3.3V on SCL as well.
I2C pull-up resistors are not closed

I thought I might have messed up the soldering so I swiped my iron another time on all the pins and ensured a proper connection. After that didn't work I replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> with another new chip from my reel but the same issue stays.

Where to look? There aren't many components connected to <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA</SIGNAL> and I'm starting to suspect the SMC. But all other sensors come back properly so I don't know.

Thanks in advance!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery
threads.message: Have you tried another battery?? BIL unplugged?? other than that, SMC issue..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery
threads.message:
3 different batteries tried so far, BIL has been unplugged.

It just sounds so unlikely for the SMC to just fail on just one I2C line with no other issues with the system at all. Replacing the SMC has been a pain in the ass before so I always try to keep it as a last solution

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery
threads.message: Pulled off the battery indicator. otherwise 99% is the SMC. I've seen a lot, when <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> got a burnt hole, the charging function would be fucked and SMC needs to replaced..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery
threads.message: especially when you see"X" in the OS

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery
threads.message:
Bummer, a dead SMC it is then. Will try to replace

Is there a secret trick to getting these on right? I'm always struggling more then I feel that I should be, just positing and keeping them positioned while using the hot air.
Maybe it's just more of a skill you get better at every time..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery
threads.message:
2011 model is pretty easy to do. it's 0.45 balls..takes a minute or two to reball. 

I usually use a led flash light, the very bright one, shine the light and try to look right at the contact between the SMC and the soldering points on the board, and just move it until they kinda line up.

It is hard to see and make sure 100% precise,but it's good enough to finish the job. 
and don't use too much flux(otherwise would flow around then you heat it),  hot air it then usually then the balls melt ,make the SMC go to the right position

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does not detect battery in OS, not charging or booting from battery
threads.message:
I wanted to let everyone know that replacing the SMC fixed the issue, reballing indeed was quite easy and went right the first time.

ASD comes back with passed

Thanks again!
